title: Online onsite admission test Radio Navigation v24.2

questions.query: Regarding A3 modulation, the number (3) means the carrier wave is...

options.text: interrupted three times per minute in order to add Morse-code information.

questions.query: Frequency modulation is used in the...

options.text: GPS system to synchronise the satellite clock  and the receiver clock.
CVOR system for the transmission of the reference signal.
ILS system for the modulation of the 90 and 150 Hz navigation signals.

questions.query: Regarding amplitude modulation (AM)...

options.text: single side band (SSB) needs a smaller bandwidth than double side band (DSB).
the carrier wave is modulated on the information signal.
the larger the volume of the information signal, the larger the bandwidth.

questions.query: The propagation speed of radio waves is...

options.text: 300 000 km/h but only at 15 deg C.

questions.query: A rotating, horizontal dipole antenna transmits a...

options.comment:
Correct.

Horizontal antennas transmit a horizontal electric field which is the polarisation direction.

questions.query: A vertical dipole antenna has a polar diagram in the shape of a...

Which antenna has the least number of lobes?

 

Note:

No reflector!
An aeroplane at an altitude of 3000 ft, has a radio horizon of approximately...
Radio waves without skywaves exist...

options.text: at frequencies with wavelengths less than 10 meters.

questions.query: ‘Fading’ is the property that the signal strenght...
Super refraction is due to a(n)...

options.text: very high seawater surface temperature, for example in tropical coastal seas.
inversion (increasing temperature with altitude) and/or a sharp decrease of the relative humidity with altitude.
abnormally high ionisation density caused by more intense sun-spot activity.
high static charge of cumulonimbi caused by thunderstorms.

questions.query: VDF for aeronautical use provides service in the frequency band from...
The magnetic direction from a non-directional radio beacon (NDB) is called...
QDM is the...

options.text: magnetic direction from a station or beacon.
true direction to a station or beacon.

questions.query:
Which of the following radio systems is used by ATC to provide ground direction finding?

  1. VDF;
  2. ADF;
  3. NDB;
  4. VOR.

Which of the following statements regarding NDB's is correct?

  1. Locators always transmits non-directional;
  2. Radio Broadcast Stations can always be used for NBD navigation;
  3. Oceanic NDB's can never be found at land.
The NDB-bearing that is taken by an ADF receiver, is shown as a...

options.text: TB, if the ADF is connected to a gyromagnetic compass.
RB, if the bearing indicator is not connected to any compass system.
MB, independent of the used compass system.
CB, if the indicator is a fixed card indicator.

questions.query: An important difference between an Airway NDB and a Locator NDB is...

options.text: transmission power: airway NDB's transmit more power; locator NDB's transmit less power.
radiation pattern: airway NDB's transmits non-directional; locator NDB's transmits directional.
siting: airway NDB's outside airports; locator NDB's at airports.
frequency band: airway NDB's between 190-1750 kHz; locator NDB's between 108-118 MHz.

questions.query: One, single loop antenna can be found at...
The transmission of an aviation NDB is...

options.text: in the LF/MF band with a 1350 Hz AM Morse ident.
non-directional with a range that depends on the type of beacon.

questions.query: According to ICAO specifications, the characteristics of a Locator signal are...

options.text: a reduced transmitter power with optimum reception just above the beacon.
horizontal polarisation of the transmitted signal with a cone of confusion.
NON/A2A type of transmission in the LF/MF band.
a voice ident consisting of 3 words per minute.

questions.query: The reception of a VOT will result in an RMI indication, that is...

options.text: dependent of the position of the aircraft.

questions.query: Which statement concerning the VOR is correct?

options.text: The tail of the RMI needle shows the difference in depth of modulation (DDM) between the 30 Hz reference signal and the 30 Hz variable signal.
options.comment: No DDM at VOR but a phase comparison.

options.text: The radial is the angle between magnetic north and the direction of the great circle from the aircraft to the beacon.
The radial is fixed by the magnetic direction of the great circle from the beacon to the aircraft
The tip of the RMI needle points in the magnetic direction from the beacon to the aircraft.

questions.query: Which statement about CVOR and DVOR is correct?

options.text: A CVOR has a carrier wave that is AM; a DVOR has a carrier wave that is FM.
The variable signals of CVOR and DVOR rotate in opposite directions.
CVORS are used in terminal areas; DVOR are used at airways.
CVORs transmit in the VHF band; DVORs transmit in the UHF band.

questions.query: A correct description of a VOT is...

options.text: A beacon that gives a certain radial that is indicated on a VOR checkpoint.
A special beacon that gives the aircraft installation the impression that the aircraft is on radial 360.
A beacon that is positioned near a terminal and that operates at reduced power.
A monitor station that monitors the VOR transmissions.

questions.query: Which statement is true for a VOR?

options.text: VOR's have monitoring stations at the boundary of their designated operational coverage.
The accuracy of a TVOR is better than that of an airway VOR.
The transmission power of a VOT and an TVOR is the same.

questions.query: In aircraft, a bearing of a VOR station can be taken by the...
When the plan range between a DME interrogator at FL350, and a transponder at SL is 200 NM, the calculated slant range is...

options.text: not possible as this distance exceeds the designated operational coverage (DOC) range of the DME.

questions.query:
An A320neo at FL360 is at 10 NM plan range from a DME with an elevation of 1000 ft.

QNH is 1013 hPa.

 

The DME reading in the aircraft will most likely be...

options.comment:
Only large, modern aircraft fly at 36000 ft.

These aircraft have their DME indication adapted to the altitude showing plan range instead of slant range.

questions.query:
An aircraft flies outbound from a VOR/DME station and crosses the border of the designated operational coverage area.

As soon as the DME-signal is no longer received, the DME interrogator will...

options.text: immediately switch to the 'search mode' and start to interrogate with maximum 150 pp/second.
interrogate in the 'tracking mode' with a maximum of 30 pp/second until another station is tuned.
in case of a 'static memory' show the last determined slant range for about 10 seconds, before switching back to the 'auto standby' mode.

questions.query: The constant duty cycle of a DME...

options.text: is a system in which the gain of the ground based receiver gain is varied in such a way that the 90-100 strongest signals are answered.
lets the airborne based interrogator transmit squitter pulses when there is no contact with a ground station.
makes sure DME channels are paired to VOR frequencies.

questions.query: Which statement is correct regarding ILS-indications?

options.text: When passing the outer marker (OM), the white light will come on at a rate of 400 Hz.
At an ILS/DME the station delay is adapted in order to show the remaining distance to the end of the runway.
The calibration of the course deviation indicator (CDI) depends on the position of the course pointer (CP).
Just before a normal glide-path (GP) intercept, the GP-pointer will have an upward deflection.
options.comment:
Correct.

The GP is intercepted from below to prevent interception of false glide slopes.

questions.query: The minimum range of the ILS localiser transmitter is...

options.text: 25 NM in a sector 17° to both sides of the centreline.
40 NM to an elevation of 1.75 times the glide path angle.
25 NM in a sector of 10° and 17 NM in a sector of 35° on both sides of the centreline.

questions.query: When the ILS signal suffers from scalloping, there are...

options.text: large changes or bends which can not be followed by the aircraft.
rapid changes or variations which can not be followed by the aircraft but are visible on the ILS indicator.
slight changes or bends which can be followed by the aircraft.
rapid changes or bends which can be followed by the aircraft.

questions.query: Which statement on ILS is true?

options.text: The primary localizer-coverage area consists of a sector of 10° on both sides of the localizer centerline with a range of 25 NM.
The ILS distance information is modulated on the localiser carrier wave.

questions.query: The wave length of the Marker Beacon transmission is...
Which statement for airborne ILS instrumentation is true?

options.text: A filter behind the UHF-receiver demodulates the 90 and 150 Hz signals of the localizer beacon.
Marker beacons are received with the UHF-receivers
The DME-part of an ILS must be manually tuned.
When there are no modulation components on the carries, the DDM is zero and there wil be a flag warning.
options.comment:
When the two modulation components of either LOC or GP are present, and the DDM is zero, the associated deviation bar is centred.

When there are no modulation components, the DDM is also zero and only then there will be a flag warning.

questions.query: The operational capacity of an ILS is limited by...

options.text: the ILS facility performance: a CAT 3 ILS can handle more aircraft than a CAT 1/2 ILS.

questions.query: Which statement on ILS critical- and sensitive areas is true?

options.text: The critical area is always smaller than the sensitive area.
The critical area extends over an area with a range of 17 NM and a width of 70 degrees; the sensitive area extends over an area with a range 25 NM and a width of 20 degrees.
In the critical area no objects are allowed; in the sensitive area objects must not exceed certain dimensions.
In the critical area objects may cause beam bends; in the sensitive area objects may cause scalloping.

questions.query:
An MLS has an azimuth beam that sweeps with a rate of 1 Hz.

 

When the time difference between the TO scan and the FR scan is zero (0), the aircraft is...

options.comment:
At the centerline the time difference is somewhere between zero (0 s) and max (1 s).

When the delta t is zero, the aircraft is at the outer edge of the coverage area where the FR scan begins.

options.text: at the outer edge of the coverage area where the TO scan begins.
at the outer edge of the coverage area where the FR scan begins.

questions.query: The execution of segmented approaches with MLS is only possible if the ground installation is equipped with a...
The big advantage of MLS compared to ILS is that...

options.text: MLS is less sensitive for multipath signals than ILS.
MLS has a larger range in the direction of the extended centerline than ILS.
MLS has monitoring stations resulting in a better integrity than ILS.
MLS requires less antenna systems than ILS.

questions.query: Contrary to ILS, MLS does NOT need...

options.text: special receivers in the aircraft, because use is made of the existing DME receiver.
separate antennas to receive the various components, because all information is transmitted on one frequency.
DME receivers, because distance information is obtained via the scanning beams.
dedicated ground antennas for all of its components, because all information is tranmitted via a single rotating beam.

questions.query:
The pulse power of radar, increases with pulse...

  1. frequency;
  2. amplitude;
  3. length.
The minimum radar range is determined by the...
A parabolic antenna with a diameter of 18 inch and a frequency of 10 MHz, has a beam width of...
The wave length of a radar determines the...
A long-range, ground surveillance-radar has a range of approximately...
Which statement regarding ground radar in aviation is correct?

options.text: Ground radar can be a primary radar or a secondary radar.
Ground radar can be a pulse radar or a continuous wave radar.
Ground radar can be an interrogator or a transponder.
Ground radar can have a stationary antenna or a rotating antenna.

questions.query: The antenna of the Surface Movement Radar (SMR) rotates at a high rpm in order to...

options.text: refresh the actual position information of relatively fast moving objects.
get a very sharp and detailed image.
compensate for the long pulse and low PRF.
create a small beam with a high azimuth (or bearing) resolution.

questions.query: Short-range, aerodrome radars for traffic on airports will have wavelengths of approximately a few...
An airborne weather radar (AWR) uses interrogation...

options.text: pulse with a length of 3.2 cm for best reflective properties.
pulses of a constant frequency, amplitude, width and rate.
pulses transmitted at a random frequency to detect possible turbulent clouds.
pulse pairs in a random order to allow lock-on on its own replies.

questions.query: Regarding tilt management of airborne weather radars, the antenna tilt has to be set to a higher value if...

options.text: the altitude increases and the selected range is larger.
the altitude decreases and the selected range is larger.
the altitude decreases and the selected range is smaller
the altitude increases and the selected range is smaller

questions.query: Path Attenuation Correction (PAC) is a technique used in in modern weather radars to...

options.text: detect and predict the path of a heavy rainshower.
compensate for the absorption and reflection of radar energy caused by heavy precipitation.
correct for the loss of signal strenght when traveling large distances.
find turbulence by looking for fast moving targets.

questions.query: Sensitivity Timing Control (STC) in airborne weather radars is used to...

options.text: account for weaker echoes from targets at larger distances.
automatically adapt the range until the nearest rainshower is shown.
compensate for the weakening of the pulses when passing rainshowers.

questions.query: Weather radar information can be improved by...
Airborne weather radar operates in which frequency band?
A Mode-A interrogation requests...

A transponder has the following settings:

  • OFF
  • SBY
  • ON
  • ALT

Which setting represents Mode-S?
Which of the following statements regarding secondary radar is correct?

options.text: In Mode-C, the pressure altitude is transmitted in 50 ft increments which means the altitude can be read within 100 ft.
The Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is transmitted automatically, and independent of the interrogation signal.
Secondary radar uses a single-pulse whose amplitude is a measure for the type of interrogation.
The ‘reply’ lamp is on when the transponder is transmitting.

questions.query: A secondary radar requires less transmission power than a primary radar because...

options.text: the interrogation signal only has to travel outbound.
the pulse repetition frequency, the pulse width and the pulse amplitude are lower.

questions.query: The 'S' in Mode-S stands for...

options.text: secondary radar.
selective addressing.
surveillance radar.

questions.query: The operating principle of a satellite navigation system is measuring the...
Regarding GPS and GLONASS, it can be stated that both systems...

options.text: can make use of each others satellites.
use two frequencies for their civil code.

questions.query: The GPS ‘pseudo range’ is so-called for, because the...
The clock correction signals in the GPS navigation message allow for the correction of the...
The American GPS-NAVSTAR lacks (is missing)...

options.text: sensitivity, availability and monitoring.
accuracy, measuring range and alerting.
tolerance, functionality and integrity.
accuracy, availability and integrity.

questions.query:
The reception of four SV's will - most probably - NOT result in a position fix when all four SV's...

  1. are below the five degrees elevation mask angle;
  2. are within five degrees relative bearing from each other;
  3. have the same polarisation;
  4. are in one plane.
The advantage of a GNSS receiver over a GPS receiver is...

options.text: a GNSS receiver can be used worldwide.
a GNSS receiver has a more effective RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) function.
a GNSS receiver uses two frequencies to determine the IPD (ionospheric propagation delay).

questions.query: An accurate, 3D GPS-fix requires at least...
The availability of the US GPS-NAVSTAR satellite navigation system is augmented through the use of...

options.text: a satellite based augmentation system such as WAAS or EGNOS.
a connection with on-board inertial navigation systems.

questions.query: Differential GPS (DGPS) is...

options.text: calculating and transmitting differential corrections to receivers in the vicinity.
monitoring and comparing differences between two receivers
measuring and indicating an accurate GPS position using the L1 and L2 frequency.
comparing and adjusting the GPS position with help of a second navigation system like GLONASS.

questions.query: RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring...

options.text: monitors the satellites via the monitor-stations spread over the earth.
delivers integrity data to the satellite via the up-link stations after the determination of the correct ephemerides by the master control station.
discovers unreliable satellites with a program in the receiver.
determines differential corrections that can be sent to the users (receivers).

questions.query: EGNOS improves GPS accuracy by...

options.text: transmitting differential corrections via a local VHF datalink.
offering an extra satellite navigation system for position fixing.
offering an extra ranging capability for a more optimum DOP.

questions.query: The geostationary Inmarsat satellites, will for endorsement of GPS...

options.text: only generate transmissions for the US WAAS; the EU EGNOS uses other SV’s.
perform the function of a pseudolite in polar areas.

questions.query: Differential GPS is an application that...

options.text: compares the reception of a double GPS installation in the aircraft to measure aircraft attitude.
determines the position by measuring the differences in the pseudo ranges of the different satellites.
derives the changes in the runtime measurement to calculate the three dimensional velocity vector.
determines the errors in the pseudo ranges within a limited area.

questions.query: The US WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) makes use of...
In GBAS, the differential correction signals are applied to correct for...
GBAS uses for its differential correction signals a datalink that operates between...
In PBN, linear lateral performance requirements are expressed in...

In which phase(s) of flight does PBN require an angular laterally guided operation?

  1. oceanic/remote;
  2. en-route;
  3. terminal;
  4. approach.
What is the validity period of the AIRAC navigation database cycle?

options.text: 2 weeks for the primary- and 2 weeks for the secondary navigation database.

questions.query: RNAV 5 means the aircraft is...

options.text: within 5 degrees from the track to the active waypoint.
100 - 5 = 95% of the flight time on the desired track.
within 5 miles from the track to the active waypoint.
options.comment: Even when the aircraft is on the track, it may be 5 NM ahead or behind the calculated position.

questions.query: The path terminator 'FA' is...

options.text: a path from a fix to an altitude

questions.query: What is the difference between the path terminators TF and CF?

options.text: TF is a time to a fix; CF is a course to a fix.
TF is a track from one fix to another fix; CF is a course to a fix.
TF is a time to a fix; CF is a circle to a fix.
TF is a ground path to a fix; CF is an air path to a fix.

questions.query:
TD193

What comprises the Total System Error (TSE) in PBN operations?

options.text: TSE = PDE2 + FTE2 + NSE2.
TSE = ground station error + space vehicle error + airborne equipment error.
TSE = transmitter error + propagation error + receiver error + reading error.

questions.query: Which of the following options describes one of the functions of a simple RNAV navigation computer?

options.text: Calculation of cross-track distance (XTK) during an NDB-approach.
Transformation of measurements from a colocated VOR/DME-station to 'track and distance' to a selected phantom waypoint.
Performance monitoring and alerting of a ground station by built-in software.
Updating the dead-reckoning (DR) position with a selection of two of the most powerful transmitters.

questions.query: The AIRAC navigation database cycle is valid for a period of...
In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is shown as...

options.comment: The flight technical error (FTE) is no error of the navigation system, but a track keeping error of teh (auto) pilot.

questions.query: An RNP Approach to LNAV minima is a non-precision approach that uses...

options.text: GNSS for lateral guidance and barometric altititude for vertical reference.
LNAV for vertical guidance and VNAV for vertical reference.
Localiser for vertical guidance and glideslope for vertical reference.

questions.query:
BB193

An RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima has lateral guidance based on [1] and vertical guidance based on [2].

CS193

RNAV 10 requires that aircraft operating in oceanic and remote areas are equipped with at least two independent and servicable LRNSs comprising an...

  1. INS;
  2. IRS-FMS;
  3. GNSS
  4. VOR/DME.

options.text: 1, 2, 3 or 4.
1, 2 or 3.
1 only.
1 or 2.

questions.query: In order to fly an RNP APCH, select the approach template from a valid, and up-to-date...

options.text: internal navigation data storage device such as a FMS, which is part of the certified aircraft configuration.
external navigation data storage device such as a tablet, which is not part of the certified aircraft configuration.
external navigation data storage device such as a hard-copy booklet holding printed versions of all type of approaches.
